page.title: International Youth Meeting Center in Oświęcim/Auschwitz

revision.comment: Bot: fix deprecated Citation Style 1 parameters ([[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/NihlusBOT 9|Task 9]])
revision.text:
{{quote box |width=30% |fontsize=100% |source=—Jonathan Webber (2006)<ref name=Webber /> |quote=Auschwitz as a place of memorial does not offer answers; it merely shocks people into asking questions — and especially the subversive questions. Perhaps this is its true role. But it can also (should also) be seen as a place of healing, through dialogue ... Over the last nineteen years, three independent educational centers have in fact been set up in the vicinity of the museum: first (in the 1980s) a German-Polish youth center, then a Catholic center, and most recently (in 2000) a [[Oświęcim Synagogue|Jewish center]] ... Collectively, the establishment of these centers means that Auschwitz is not only a site of mourning and meditation, a site of memory, but also a site of researching, learning, and encounter, interreligious or otherwise. The growth of these institutions hints at new strategies emerging for a long-term future.}} The '''International Youth Meeting Center in Oświęcim/Auschwitz''' is an educational institution whose campus lies between the center of the Polish city of [[Oświęcim]] and the former [[Auschwitz concentration camp|German concentration camp of Auschwitz]]. More than one million persons, mostly Jewish and Polish, were murdered at Auschwitz during the [[World War II|Second World War]] (1939–1945). Proposed in 1971, the Center was opened in 1986 following years of planning, negotiations, and fundraising.<ref name=AP /><ref name=CSM /> It seeks to "develop the understanding of [[National Socialism]] and its consequences, particularly among young Germans, through dialogue and encounter between people of different origins", and is particularly engaged with Germans and Poles, Christians and Jews.<ref name=ARSP /> In 2010, the Center hosted more than 17,000 overnight stays by youth groups participating in its programs.<ref name=ASF10 /> Many young Germans and Austrians have held year-long voluntary positions at the Center that satisfy their [[civilian service]] (''Zivildienst'') responsibility. One of these, [[Robert Thalheim]], wrote and directed the German-language dramatic film ''[[And Along Come Tourists]]'' (2007) that features the Center and its activities.
The Polish and German names for the Center are '''''Międzynarodowy Dom Spotkań Młodzieży w Oświęcimiu''''' and '''''Internationale Jugendbegegnungsstätte in Oświęcim/Auschwitz''''', respectively; the two names are conjoined in the abbreviation MDSM/IJBS for the Center.
==History== The idea for the construction of a youth meeting center in Poland came from [[:de:Volker von Törne|Volker von Törne]] (1934–1980), who saw an opportunity for creating it following the signing of the 1970 [[Treaty of Warsaw (1970)|Treaty of Warsaw]] between [[West Germany]] and Poland. von Törne was a poet and then business manager of the [[Action Reconciliation Service for Peace (ARSP)]], which is a private German organization (''Aktion Sühnezeichen Friedensdienst'') working towards reconciliation with countries and peoples harmed during German occupation in World War II. Following von Törne's death in 1980, [[:de:Christoph Heubner|Christoph Heubner]] led the project for ARSP.<ref name=CSM /><ref name=VW /> In a 1986 interview, Heubner explained the importance of placing the Center near Auschwitz, which "symbolized the lowest point in German-Polish history, the lowest point in Jewish-German relations, one of the lowest points in man's inhumanity to man. The motivation to speak with one another is greater there. The greater emotion opens people up more for dialogue than would be the case in [[Masuria]] [an area in northeast Poland] or in some sunny mountain meadow."<ref name=CSM />
In the late 1970s and early 1980s the proposal was very controversial. The location of the buildings, the architecture of the project, the operations as well as the Polish partner for the ARSP were contentious issues. In 1978, [[Andreas Maislinger]] unsuccessfully approached President [[Rudolf Kirchschläger]] about Austrian support for the project.<ref name=Maislinger /><ref name=Buchholz />
The project received the support of many survivors of the concentration camps at [[Dachau concentration camp|Dachau]], [[Stutthof concentration camp|Stutthof]], [[Buchenwald concentration camp|Buchenwald]] and Auschwitz, and by December 1985 a turning point was reached. Alfred Przybylski, former prisoner #471 at the Auschwitz camp and the representative of the Union of Polish Architects, supported by the plans drawn up by German architect Helmut Morlok, contributed decisively to the realization of the project.<ref name=Morlok /><ref name=DAB /><ref name=DAB2 /><ref name=Toporowsky />
After obtaining contributions of 4.6 million Deutschmarks ($2.1 million), sufficient for 2/3 of the construction costs, ground was finally broken in May 1986. The handoff of the initial buildings to the foundation that operates it was celebrated on December 7, 1986, which was the sixteenth anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Warsaw.<ref name=AP /> The entire building project was completed in October, 1998. The Center is primarily supported by the Polish municipality of Oświęcim and by the ARSP,<ref name=mdsm /> which sponsors three such centers.<ref name=ARSP /><ref name=Morlok /> In 2010, the Center hosted more than 17,000 overnight stays by youth groups participating in its programs.<ref name=ASF10 />
The Center has become well known in German-speaking Europe following release of the dramatic film ''Am Ende kommen Touristen'' (2007) (''[[And Along Come Tourists]]''), which was partly filmed at the Center. The film was written and directed by [[Robert Thalheim]]. While the film's characters and story are fictional, in writing the screenplay Thalheim drew from his own experience as a German [[civilian service]] worker at the Center in 1996-97.<ref name=Louk>{{cite web |title=Interview with 'And Along Come Tourists' Director Robert Thalheim |work=[[The Epoch Times]] |last=Louk |first=Lidia |date=September 14, 2007 |url=http://www.theepochtimes.com/news/7-9-14/59762.html}}</ref>
==Facilities== The Center is on one bank of the [[Soła|Soła river]], and consists of several pavilions laid out around a large garden. There is a forum, a multi-purpose room, a library, and four seminar rooms. There are about one hundred beds, as well as a campground and a sports field.
Katrin Buchholz has described the architecture as follows: "Modesty in construction and form, simplicity in the interior furnishings, ... the center of the campus is a meeting place that is open in all directions ... where all can move or loiter freely and unobserved, and in which one can find community but also security, as well as time and space to be alone."<ref name=KBuchholz />
==Programming== The Center sponsors activities of several types, including workshops to bring together groups of Polish and German students, seminars and development programs for adults and teachers, and exhibitions for general visitors. Groups using the Center typically stay for four or five days. In addition to visits to the remains of the concentration camps Auschwitz I, Auschwitz-Birkenau, and Auschwitz III-Monowitz, groups can plan excursions in the area, especially to the city of [[Kraków]], and conversations can be arranged with experts on the major concerns of the Center.
The Center has been among the sites <!--Einsatzstellen-->for the work of young German and Austrian citizens doing [[civilian service]] (''Zivildienst'') sponsored by the ARSP, the German ''[[:de:Internationaler Bund|Internationaler Bund]]'', and by the [[Austrian Holocaust Memorial Service]].<ref name=Ainetter />
==See also== *[[Anne Frank Educational Centre (Frankfurt)]]. A youth meeting center supported by the [[Anne Frank Foundation]]. *[[Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum]]. A museum and research institution associated with the Auschwitz camps. *[[Krzyżowa, Świdnica County|International Youth Meeting Centre in Krzyżowa]]. A second youth meeting center in Poland that is devoted to dialogue and reconciliation between Poland and Germany. The Centre was founded after an historic 1989 meeting of Polish Prime Minister [[Tadeusz Mazowiecki]] and the German Federal Chancellor [[Helmut Kohl]]. *[[Eliezer Ben Yehuda's residence#The International Meeting Center|International Youth Meeting Center in Israel]]. A second ARSP-sponsored youth meeting center in Israel. *[[Oświęcim Synagogue]]. The 1913 synagogue was restored and re-opened in 2000; it serves the small local community as well as visitors. The synagogue is part of the Auschwitz Jewish Center (''Centrum Żydowskie w Oświęcimiu''), which also incorporates a museum and an education center.

Service as an Alternative to Civilian Service |first=Bernhard |work=Unipress (Innsbruck) |last=Ainetter |date=October 1997 |url=http://old.auslandsdienst.at/press/archive/unipress_10.1997.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531124436/http://old.auslandsdienst.at/press/archive/unipress_10.1997.html |archivedate=2014-05-31 |df= }}</ref> <ref name=AP>{{cite news |url=http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1986/West-German-Polish-officials-open-Auschwitz-youth-center/id-23bfed63a3ef7efbf243f056b145d6b6 |work=Associated Press (AP) |date=December 7, 1986 |title=West German, Polish officials open Auschwitz youth center}}</ref> <ref name=ASF10>{{cite book |title=Jahresbericht 2010 |language=German |trans-title=Annual Report 2010 |page=39 |last=Meier |first=Anna |url=https://www.asf-ev.de/fileadmin/scripts/download.php?path=fileadmin/Redaktion/Dateien/Publikationen/Jahresberichte/ASF_JB2010_web_optimiert.pdf}}</ref> <ref name=ARSP>{{cite web |title=France, Israel, Poland: Three international Meeting Centres |publisher=Action Reconciliation Service for Peace |url=https://www.asf-ev.de/nc/en/about-us/organisation-structure/internationale-begegnungssttten0.html}}</ref> <ref name=Buchholz>{{cite journal |last=Buchholz |first=Christian |title=Spiritualität und politische Bildung in der Internationalen Jugendbegegnungsstätte Auschwitz: Ein 'heilsames Haus' |language=German |trans-title=Spirituality and political development in the International Youth Meeting Center at Auschwitz: A house for healing |url=http://pfarrerverband.medio.de/pfarrerblatt/index.php?a=show&id=3106 |journal=Deutsches Pfarrerblatt |date=January 2012}} History of the Center on the occasion of its 25th anniversary, including 25 literature references.</ref> <ref name=KBuchholz>{{cite book |last=Buchholz |first= Katrin |title=Die Internationale Jugendbegegnungsstätte Auschwitz und ihr Auftrag zur Verständigung und Versöhnung – Religionspädagogische und didaktische Perspektiven |year=2000 |page=62ff |quote=Bescheidenheit in Konstruktion und Form, Einfachheit bei der inneren Ausstattung, … Kernstück der Anlage ist ein nach allen Richtungen offener Begegnungshof … wo sich jeder frei und unbeobachtet bewegen und aufhalten kann in der man Gemeinschaft aber auch Geborgenheit sowie Zeit und Platz für sich alleine finden kann.}} Unpublished work cited in {{cite journal |last=Buchholz |first=Christian |title=Spiritualität und politische Bildung in der Internationalen Jugendbegegnungsstätte Auschwitz: Ein 'heilsames Haus' |language=German |url=http://pfarrerverband.medio.de/pfarrerblatt/index.php?a=show&id=3106 |journal=Deutsches Pfarrerblatt |date=January 2012}}</ref> <ref name=CSM>{{cite news |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/1986/1229/oholo-f.html |work=The Christian Science Monitor |title=Auschwitz youth center founded on need for emotion, reflection. Group sees donation of center as victory for healing process |date=December 29, 1986 |last=Pond |first=Elizabeth}} Article published on the occasion of the Center's opening; it incorporates parts of an interview with [[:de:Christian Heubner|Christian Heubner]]. Elizabeth Pond was a foreign correspondent for the ''Christian Science Monitor'' from 1967-1988 (see [http://www.unc.edu/depts/diplomat/AD_Issues/amdipl_15/pond_15.html#Anchor "Europe in the 21st Century"]). She is the author of numerous books and articles on foreign policy and international affairs.</ref> <ref name=DAB>{{cite web |title=Alfred Przybylski: Häftling 471 – ein großer Humanist |language=German |trans-title=Alfred Przybylski: prisoner 471 – a great humanist |url=http://dabonline.de/2011/11/20/haftling-471-%E2%80%93-ein-groser-humanist/ |work=Deutsches Architektenblatt |date=November 20, 2011}}</ref> <ref name=DAB2>{{cite journal |url=http://dabonline.de/2011/11/30/auf-der-anderen-seite-der-welt/ |title=Auf der anderen Seite der Welt |language=German |trans-title=On the other side of the world |date=November 30, 2011 |work=Deutsches Architektenblatt}} History of the Center and especially of its architecture.</ref> <ref name=Maislinger>{{cite journal|last=Maislinger |first=Andreas |url=http://www.auslandsdienst.at/de/projekt/pressearchiv-1979-1990/internationale-jugendbegegnungsst%C3%A4tte-auschwitz-kritisches |title=Internationale Jugendbegegnungsstätte Auschwitz |journal=Kritisches Christentum |volume=33 |date=December 1979 |language=German |trans-title=The International Youth Meeting Center in Auschwitz |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004220537/http://www.auslandsdienst.at/de/projekt/pressearchiv-1979-1990/internationale-jugendbegegnungsst%C3%A4tte-auschwitz-kritisches |archivedate=2013-10-04 |df= }}</ref> <ref name=mdsm>{{cite web |url=http://www.mdsm.pl/de/stiftung/ueber-die-stiftung |title=Über die Stiftung |language=German |trans-title=About the Foundation |publisher=MDSM/IJBS}}</ref> <ref name=Morlok>{{cite web |last=Morlok |first=Helmut |title=Ein Haus des Dialogs |trans-title=A House of Dialogue |url=https://www.asf-ev.de/de/ueber-uns/organisation/internationale-begegnungssttten/25-jahre-ijbs.html |publisher=Action Reconciliation Service for Peace |year=2011 |language=German}} A history of the Center written by its architect on the occasion of its 25th anniversary.</ref> <ref name=Toporowsky>{{cite web |title=Helmut Morlok: vom Adolf-Hitler-Schüler zum Architekten der Versöhnung |language=German |trans-title=Helmut Morlok: from Hitler youth to an architect of reconciliation |url=http://www.nationalpark-eifel.de/data/inhalt/3_Helmut_Morlok_auf_Vogelsang_und_am_CFG_1268140403.pdf |year=2009 |first1=Georg |last1=Toporowsky |first2=Bruno |last2=Müller |first3=Jürgen |last3=Drewes |publisher=[[Eifel National Park]]}}</ref> <ref name=VW>{{cite web |url=http://www.auschwitz.info/e/events_statements/110316_vw_heubner.html |publisher=[[International Auschwitz Committee]] |date=March 16, 2011 |title=VW honours Christoph Heubner}} The Volkswagen company sends employees to the Center annually, and has supported it financially since 1986. In 2011 the company honored [[:de:Christian Heubner|Christian Heubner]], who has long been associated with the Center and with the International Auschwitz Committee.</ref> <ref name=Webber>{{cite book |title=Religion, Violence, Memory, and Place |editor1-last=Stier |editor1-first=Owen Baruch |editor2-last=Landres |editor2-first=J. Shawn |chapter=Memory, Religion, and Conflict at Auschwitz: A Manifesto |last=Webber |first=Jonathan |page=66 |publisher=Indiana University Press |year=2006 |isbn=9780253347992 |oclc=70122483 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mG3jxSTEHo4C&pg=PA66}} Webber's quote refers to the International Youth Meeting Center (the present article), the [http://www.cdim.pl/en/home-page/the-centre Centre for Dialogue and Prayer in Oświęcim] opened in 1992, and the [[Auschwitz Jewish Center]] opened in 2000. Webber is presently a professor at [[Jagiellonian University]]; he is a British social anthropologist with special expertise on European Judaism and European Jews. See {{cite web |title=Jonathan Webber |url=http://www.ces.uj.edu.pl/en_US/about-ces/faculty-and-staff/faculty/jonathan-webber |publisher=Jagiellonian University |accessdate=2013-06-13}}</ref> }}
==Further reading== *{{cite journal |last=Allen |first=Michael Thad |title=Realms of Oblivion: The Vienna Auschwitz Trial |url=http://michaelthadallen.com/Homepage.pages/articles/CEH.Page.Proofs.Last.KLA.pdf |journal=Central European History |volume=40 |year=2007 |pages=1–32 |doi=10.1017/s0008938907000787}} Alfred Przybylski's testimony is noted briefly in this article about a trial leading to the dismissal of charges against two of the planners of the Auschwitz concentration camp. *{{cite web |url=http://www.berlin.de/landespressestelle/archiv/2002/08/15/07558/index.html |language=German |title=Verdienstkreuz für Christoph Heubner |trans-title=Order of merit for Christoph Heubner |publisher= |date=August 15, 2002 |last=John |first=Thomas}} Press release on the occasion of the award of Germany's [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany|Knight's Cross]] to Christoph Heubner, who worked on negotiations and planning for the Center during the 1980s. *{{cite web |url=http://www.mk.niedersachsen.de/portal/live.php?navigation_id=1820&article_id=5702&_psmand=8 |language=German |title=Bundesverdienstkreuz für Verdienste um die Aussöhnung mit dem Nachbarland Polen |trans-title=Order of Merit for service towards reconciliation with the neighbor country Poland |year=2004 |publisher=Niedersächsisches Kultusministerium |accessdate=2014-05-24}} Press release on the occasion of the award of Germany's Knight's Cross to Helmut Morlok, the architect of the Center.
==External links== *{{cite web |url=http://www.mdsm.pl/de/ |title=Internationale Jugendbegegnunstätte in Oświęcim/Auschwitz |language=German, Polish |trans-title=International Youth Meeting Center |publisher=MDSM/IJBS}} Website of the International Youth Meeting Center. *{{cite web |title=Centre for Dialogue and Prayer in Oświęcim |url=http://www.cdim.pl/en/home-page/the-centre}} This Centre near the Auschwitz camps is a Catholic institution opened in 1992. The Centre is "a place for reflection, education, sharing and prayer for all those who are moved by what happened here. The Centre commemorates the victims and contributes to creating mutual respect, reconciliation, and peace in the world." A convent is adjacent to the Centre; it was relocated there after a [[World Jewish Congress#Controversy over Catholic convent's presence at Auschwitz|controversy about the convent's original location]], which was adjacent to one of the Auschwitz concentration camps.
{{DEFAULTSORT:International Youth Meeting Center in Oswiecim Auschwitz}} [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1986]] [[Category:Student exchange]] [[Category:Peace organizations]] [[Category:Oświęcim County]] [[Category:1986 establishments in Poland]]

{{Japanese name|Itō}} {{nihongo|'''Itō Takumi'''|伊藤 卓美||extra=born in January 15, 1946 in the [[Miyagi Prefecture]], [[Japan]]}} is a prominent [[Japan]]ese [[printmaker]] and president of the [[Japan Print Society]]. His artwork has been featured on [[Japan Post]] [[postage stamps]] as well as featured in exhibitions at the [[Library of Congress]] and the [[Peabody Essex Museum]] in [[Salem, Massachusetts]]. Takumi currently teaches woodblock printing at [[Waseda University]] in [[Tokyo]].
Takumi's interest in the [[woodblock printing]] began at a young age when his father, a [[Painting|painter]], encouraged his study of the arts. Having a special interest in Japanese [[matsuri]] festivals and [[folk art]], especially [[mingei]], many of Takumi's prints explore the local cultures of Japan's rural areas, such as his own Miyagi Prefecture.
==References== * Akita, Manami. "'''Asobi wa' Kyukyoku no Yorokobi.''" Hanga Geijutsu 118, December 2002: 58-61. * Yoshida, Shozo. "''Tono Kitamami no Tohoku Minzoku Geino to Hangaka Itow Takumi.''" Gekkan Ashita, March 1987.
==External links== * [http://nipponhanga.jp/ Japan Print Society], official site.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Itow, Takumi}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Japanese printmakers]] [[Category:Japanese educators]] [[Category:Crafts educators]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Sosaku hanga artists]]

[[Image:Djamchid.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Jamshid Momtaz]] '''Jamshid Momtaz''' (born 18 June 1942 in [[İzmir]]) is an Iranian jurist and academic.
He earned his degree in Public Law at the Faculty of Law and Economy from University of Paris (1966).
In 1968, he graduated from the [[Sciences Po|Institut d'études politiques de Paris]] and held his PhD in Public Law at the Faculty of Law, Economics and Social Sciences of [[Panthéon-Assas University]] (1971). He started his career as Assistant Professor in [[University of Paris X]] (Nanterre, France) in 1968 and pursued in Iran since 1974 as Professor at the [[University of Tehran]]. From 1979 to 1982, he chaired the Center for International Studies of the University of Tehran.
Meanwhile, as an academician, Jamshid Momtaz has held teaching courses at home and abroad since 1969 at different institutions including [[Institute of Higher International Studies|Institut des hautes études internationales]] in Paris, University of Law, Economics and Social Sciences, Paris II, University of Paris X (Paris Ouest Nanterre, La Défense), University of Grenoble II (Mendes France), University of Paris XI (Jean Monnet), University of Paris XIII (Villetaneuse), University of Caen (Basse-Normandie) and visiting Professor at the [[University of Paris I]] (Panthéon Sorbonne) [http://www.univ-paris1.fr/]. He is currently teaching International humanitarian law at the School of International Relations (SIR) affiliated with the Iranian ministry of foreign affairs to the next generations of Iranian diplomats.
Advisor to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Islamic Republic of Iran and former member of the [[International Law Commission]] of the [[United Nations]] from 2000 until 2006 (President of the same committee at its 57th session in 2005 - 2006) [https://www.un.org/law/ilc/index.htm]. He is a Fellow of the Institute of International Law ([[Institut de Droit International]]) and member of several organizations :
*''[[International Committee of Red Cross]] (ICRC) Group of International Adviser [http://www.icrc.org/web/eng/siteeng0.nsf/iwpList2/Home?OpenDocument]. *''Curatorium of the [[Hague Academy of International Law]] [http://www.hagueacademy.nl/]. *''Board of Editors of the Yearbook of International Humanitarian Law (T.M.C. Asser Institute, Netherlands) [https://web.archive.org/web/20070307130340/http://www.asser.nl/index.htm]. *''Steering Committee for the International Committee of Red Cross (ICRC), Study on International Customary Law (1996-2004). *''Commission for the Settlement of Disputes Related to Confidentiality, [[Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons]] (OPCW)[http://www.opcw.org/], 1994-2004. *''More information available on Jamshid Momtaz site: http://djamchidmomtaz.com
As an expert, Jamshid Momtaz was part of the Iranian delegation in charge of nuclear talks with major powers (G5+1) [http://english.farsnews.com/newstext.aspx?nn=13930602001421].
== Articles and chapters in edited works==
Dr Momtaz is the author of more than 90 publications including books, chapters in edited works, articles in journals and yearbooks in French, English and Persian on diverse issues of international law. *''Le droit international humanitaire applicable aux conflits armés non internationaux'', Collected Courses of the Hague Academy of International Law, Tome 292, 2001, Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, The Hague/Boston/London 2002. *''Les actions au cours d'un conflit armé'', in studi di Diritto Internazionale in Onore di Gaetano Arangio Ruiz, Editoriale Scientifica, 2004 *''Le recours à l'arme nucléaire et la protection de l'environnement : l'apport de la Cour internationalede Justice'', In International Law, the International Court of Justice and Nuclear Weapons, Laurence Boisson de Chazournes and Philippe Sands (Editors), Cambridge University Press 1999. *''Did the Court Miss an Opportunity to Denounce the Erosion of the Principle Prohibiting the Use of Force ? ''Symposium Reflections on the ICJ's Oil Platforms Decisions, [[Yale Journal of International Law]], Vol. 29, Number 29, Summer 2004. *"Attribution of Conduct to the State: State Organs and Entities Empowered to Exercise Elements of Governmental Autorithy", James Crawford, Alain Pellet and Simon Olleson Edited by Oxford University Press (2010) *''More information on Jamshid Momtaz website: http://djamchidmomtaz.com *"Créer une zone exempte d’armes nucléaires au Moyen-Orient : une mission impossible ?" The 90th Birthday of Boutros Boutros-Ghali. Tribute of the Curatorial to its President. A Publication of The Hague Academy of International Law Martinus Nijhoff Publishers Leiden, Boston (2012). *"La délimitation du plateau continental du Golfe Persique: une entreprise inachevée", Law of the Sea from Grotius to the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea, Liber Amicorum Judge Hugo Caminos, Lilian Del Castillo. Edited by Brill Nijhoff (2015) *"L’attachement de la Cour internationale de justice au consensualisme judiciaire est-il sans faille ?" The Limits of International Law: Essays in honour of Joe Verhoeven, Bruylant Larmier (2015) * Garantir la nature exclusivement pacifique du programme nucléaire de l'Iran (Le plan d'action conjoint du 24 novembre 2013) in Nuclear Weapons: Strengthening the International Legal Regime, Eleven International Publishing (2016) == Books== * Le droit international humanitaire applicable aux conflits armés non internationaux, Receuil des cours de l’Académie de droit international, Tome 292, 2001, Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, The Hague / Boston / London (2002) * Rules and Institutions of International Humanitarian Law Put to the Test of Recent Armed Conflicts, with M.J. Mathewson, Hague Academy of International Law, Martinus Nijhoff Publishers Leiden, Boston (2010) ==Lectures== * [http://legal.un.org/avl/ls/Momtaz_S.html ''La sécession en droit international''] in the [http://legal.un.org/avl/lectureseries.html Lecture Series of the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law] * [http://legal.un.org/avl/faculty/Momtaz.html ''Le droit international humanitaire applicable aux conflits armés non internationaux''] in the [http://legal.un.org/avl/lectureseries.html Lecture Series of the United Nations Audiovisual Library of International Law] * Centre for International Legal Studies School of International Studies, Jawaharlal Nehru University (2006) * Training Program in Multilateral Diplomacy and International Affairs Management, UNITAR, The Hague, July 1991, August 2005, July 2007 * United Nations Audio Visual Library of International LawLecture Series, Le droit international humanitaire applicable aux conflits armés non internationaux (2007) * El Magreb y Oriente Media en la Sociedad Internacional Contemporana, Casa Arabe Madrid Universidad de Jaen, Universidad de Cordoba, Spain (2009) * United Regional Courses on International Law, Hague Academy of International Law (2014) * United Regional Courses on International Law, Addis-Ababa, Ethiopia (2012) * United Nations Audio Visual Library of International Law Lectur Series, La sécession en droit international (2015) *Institut international des droits de l'homme, Strasbourg, France 2015 et 20116

{{Infobox person | name = Jon Sudbø | image = <!-- just the name, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1961|5|3}} | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Norway | other_names = | known_for = [[Scientific fraud]] | occupation = Dentist and physician }}
'''Jon Sudbø''' (born May 3, 1961) is a [[Norway|Norwegian]] dentist, physician, and former [[medical research]]er, who was exposed as a [[scientific fraud]]ster in 2006. Over a period of several years, he fabricated results in the field of [[oncology]] which he published in leading medical journals. The article that led to his downfall, which was published in ''[[The Lancet]]'', was based on 900 patients Sudbø had fabricated entirely. The editor of ''The Lancet'' described this as the biggest scientific fraud conducted by a single researcher ever.<ref>http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Krop,_psyke_og_sundhed/Sundhedsvidenskab/Læger/Jon_Sudbø</ref>
Sudbø graduated from the [[University of Oslo]] faculty of dentistry in 1989 and the faculty of medicine in 1994, both top of his class.
Sudbø was formerly employed as a consultant oncologist at the [[Radiumhospitalet|Radium Hospital]] in Oslo and as an associate professor at the [[University of Oslo]], but as a result of the fabrication scandal, he resigned from these positions in 2006. The same year, his licenses to practice medicine and dentistry were revoked. An inquiry by the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Oslo found that most of Sudbø's work, including his doctoral dissertation, were based on fraud, and the University of Oslo revoked his [[Doctor Medicinae (Danish and Norwegian degree)|doctorate in medicine]] in 2006.<ref>{{Cite news |url = http://www.aftenposten.no/helse/article1541181.ece |title = Ferdig som lege |last = Hafstad |first = Anne |author2 = Ingeborg Moe |publisher = [[Aftenposten]] |date = 2006-11-22 |language = Norwegian |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110523203804/http://www.aftenposten.no/helse/article1541181.ece |archivedate = 2011-05-23 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url = http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article1575472.ece |title = Mister doktorgraden |publisher = [[Norsk Telegrambyrå]] via [[Aftenposten]] |date = 2006-12-19 |language = Norwegian |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070102092114/http://www.aftenposten.no/nyheter/iriks/article1575472.ece |archivedate = 2007-01-02 |df = }}</ref>
In 2007, he was granted a strictly limited license to work as an assistant dentist under supervision, and in 2009, he regained licenses to practice medicine and dentistry with some restrictions. He is currently working as an assistant dentist in [[Seljord]], [[Telemark]].
His wife [[Wanja Kildal]] was his co-author of 7 of the articles that were found to be fraudulent and subsequently retracted, while his brother [[Asle Sudbø]] was a co-author of two of these articles.
==Scandal== In January 2006 it was revealed that his October 2005 fast track submission to ''[[The Lancet]]'' was based upon fraudulent patient data.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Fraud charges against Norwegian researcher stoke confusion over painkillers |quote=Fraud accusations against a Norwegian researcher have muddied the question of whether popular over-the-counter pain relievers fight cancer or harm the heart. Norway's Comprehensive Cancer Center said over the weekend that one of its researchers admitted fabricating data used in a study that said common pain relievers, including ibuprofen (sold as Motrin and Advil) and naproxen (Naprosyn, Aleve), lowered the risk of oral cancer but heightened the risk of heart problems.... |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |date=January 17, 2006 }}</ref> The article had suggested that non-[[cyclooxygenase|COX2]]-[[Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug|NSAID]]s like [[ibuprofen]] diminish the risk of oral cancer in smokers.<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and the risk of oral cancer: a nested case-control study | author = Jon Sudbø, J.J. Lee, S.M. Lippman, J. Mork, S. Sagen, N. Flatner, A. Ristimaki, A. Sudbø, L. Mao, X. Zhou, W. Kildal, J.F. Evensen, A. Reith, [[A.J. Dannenberg]] | journal = [[The Lancet]] | date = October 2005 | volume = 366 | issue = 9494 | pages = 1359–1366 | pmid = 16226613 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67488-0 }}{{Retracted paper|{{PMID|16458751}}|intentional=yes}}</ref> However, it turned out that the whole patient material was fictional. The leader of the [[epidemiology]] division at [[Norwegian Institute of Public Health]], [[Camilla Stoltenberg]], found the article suspicious at the end of 2005 because the data was supposedly from a cancer patient database which had not yet opened.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://vitalitymagazine.com/article/medical-research-fraud/|title=Medical Research Fraud|last=Ferrie|first=Helke|date=April 2006|publisher=Vitality Magazine|accessdate=2009-04-15}}</ref> The Norwegian newspaper ''[[Dagbladet]]'' reported that of the 908 subjects in the Lancet study 250 had the same birthday.<ref>{{Cite news | publisher = [[BBC News]] | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/4617372.stm | title = Cancer study patients 'made up' | date = 2006-01-16 }}</ref>
Sudbø has later acknowledged that he has used fictional data in at least two more papers, published in the ''[[New England Journal of Medicine]]'' and the ''[[Journal of Clinical Oncology]]''.
An independent Commission of Inquiry led by [[Sweden|Swedish]] Professor Anders Ekbom, that also included a member from the [[United States|U.S.]] [[National Cancer Institute]], was set up by [[Rikshospitalet]] and the [[University of Oslo]] to discern the details of the fraud. They were also to try to identify the role of the [[Collaborative writing|co-authors]], which included, among others, Jon Sudbø's brother and wife.
In May 2006, Norwegian and Swedish media reported that the committee was investigating some 60 scientists from 6 countries, and a total of 38 articles.<ref>{{Cite news |first = Staffan |last = Kihlström |url = http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=597&a=542859 |title = 60 forskare granskas efter fuskskandal |language = Swedish |publisher = [[Dagens Nyheter]] |date = 2006-05-06 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071001110409/http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=597&a=542859 |archivedate = 2007-10-01 |df = }}</ref>
The commission reported on 30 June 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rikshospitalet.no/view/readavdi.asp?nPubID%3D6628%26department%3DEnglish |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060823045626/http://www.rikshospitalet.no/view/readavdi.asp?nPubID=6628&department=English |archivedate=2006-08-23 |df= }}</ref> The commission deemed much of Sudbø's work invalid because of manipulation and fabrication of raw data: of the 38 articles he had published since 1993, 15 were condemned as fraudulent, including his doctoral [[dissertation]].<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://www.svd.se/dynamiskt/inrikes/did_13082567.asp | title = Norskt forskarfusk allvarligare än väntat | date = 2006-07-01 | publisher = [[Svenska Dagbladet]] | language = Swedish | last = Atterstam | first = Inger }}</ref> Because of this, the dissertation and the other fraudulent articles will be [[Rescission (contract law)|rescinded]]. The commission also criticised the co-authors of Sudbø's papers. Professor Anders Ekbom, the Chair of the Commission, said: "One explanation of this catastrophe was that Sudbø was a lone wolf. Few or anyone had insight into his work". The commission found no evidence that any of his co-authors had taken part in the fraud or otherwise been party to the deceit, although Sudbø's supervisor accepted criticism for lack of vigilance and follow-up.
In November 2006 his authorizations as a physician and a dentist were revoked by the [[Norwegian Board of Health Supervision]], but in 2007 he was granted a strictly limited authorization to work as an assistant dentist.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bt.no/nyheter/innenriks/Jon-Sudboe-kan-bli-tannlege-1846261.html#.TxGfgc2DGLg |title=Jon Sudbø kan bli tannlege |publisher=Bergens Tidende |language=Norwegian |work=bt.no |date=2 June 2007 }}</ref> In 2009 he was granted restricted authorizations to practice as dentist and as a physician, however he cannot involve himself in research.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://studenttorget.no/index.php?show=3378&expand=3795,3378&artikkelid=9464 |title=Exam cheaters who got away |work=Studenttorget.no |date=4 July 2011 |accessdate=10 November 2013 |author=Meland, Ragnhild |language=Norwegian |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016031213/http://studenttorget.no/index.php?show=3378&expand=3795%2C3378&artikkelid=9464 |archivedate=16 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Effects of fraud== Rikshospitalet and the University were both criticized for "a lack of preliminary control and organization with a view to the researcher's [Sudbø's] PhD project". The hospital was also criticized for "a lack of training and consciousness-raising in respect of the researcher and other employees with a view to the rules for handling patient material, preliminary assessments of research projects and authorship" and for "a lack of leadership and routines designed to expose and deal with non-conformance with its rules of procedure".
The fraud may also have had international effects.<ref>{{Cite news |last = Hafstad |first = Anne |author2 = [[Jonathan Tisdall]] |url = http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1373320.ece |title = Cheating has international impact |publisher = [[Aftenposten]] |date = 2006-06-30 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060703202156/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1373320.ece |archivedate = 2006-07-03 |df = }}</ref> The commission could not rule out that Sudbø's false conclusions could have affected cancer patients around the world, because his findings were used by other scientists and incorporated into cancer treatments, although Sudbø's solicitor Erling O. Lyngtveit had said on behalf of his client that none of the fraudulent articles had had any consequences for patients.<ref>http://depesjer.no/saker/sudb%C3%B8-case-co-author-responsibilities-disregarded/{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Norway's scientific reputation could also be damaged by the affair, and "massive lawsuits" may be imminent from the national and international organisations that funded Sudbø's fraudulent papers.
According to the Norwegian [[news site|news website]] ''[[Depesjer]]'' ("Dispatches"), scientific experts they consulted felt that Sudbø's [[Collaborative writing|co-authors]] were "severely exploited", but also that closer observations of the [[Vancouver guidelines]] and other rules by co-authors would "hamper future attempts at publishing fabricated material".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://depesjer.no/nyheter/aktualitet/medisin/sudboe_case_co_author_responsibilities_disregarded/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2006-12-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927172028/http://depesjer.no/nyheter/aktualitet/medisin/sudboe_case_co_author_responsibilities_disregarded/ |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref> Dr. Atle Klovning, a leading European authority on [[evidence-based medicine]], said in the article that Sudbø's co-authors had probably not lived up to their responsibilities according to the Vancouver rules.
==Publications== *Sudbø J. 2001. ''Predictive markers in oral premalignancies and early stage carcinomas''. Oslo : Department of Pathology, The Norwegian Radium Hospital. {{ISBN|82-7633-163-7}}. Doctoral dissertation, University of Oslo. **'''Retracted by the university in December 2006'''

{{EngvarB|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{More footnotes|date=September 2010}} {{Infobox scientist | honorific_prefix = [[Dame]] | name = Kathleen Ollerenshaw | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|DBE}} | image = Dame Kathleen Ollerenshaw signing book.jpg | image_size = 240px | caption = Signing a book in the [[Alan Turing Building]] | birth_name = Kathleen Mary Timpson | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1912|10|01}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2014|08|10|1912|10|01}} | death_place = [[Didsbury]], England | birth_place = [[Withington]], Manchester, England | fields = [[Magic square]]
[[Lattice (order)|Lattices]] | workplaces = [[Victoria University of Manchester|University of Manchester]] | alma_mater = [[Somerville College, Oxford]] | thesis_year = 1945 | doctoral_advisor = [[Theodore William Chaundy]] | spouse = {{marriage|Robert Ollerenshaw
|1939|1986|end=his death}} | children = 2 }} '''Dame Kathleen Mary Ollerenshaw''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|DBE}} ([[né]]e '''Timpson'''; 1 October 1912 – 10 August 2014) was a British mathematician and politician who was [[List of mayors of Manchester|Lord Mayor of Manchester]] from 1975 to 1976 and an advisor on educational matters to [[Margaret Thatcher]]'s government in the 1980s. ==Early life and education== Born Kathleen Mary Timpson in [[Withington]], Manchester, where she attended [[Lady Barn House School]] (1918–1926).{{cn|date=April 2018}} She was a grandchild of the founder of the [[Timpson (retailer)|Timpson]] shoe repair business, who had moved to Manchester from [[Kettering]] and established the business there by 1870.{{cite book |title=Manchester Memoirs |first=Kahtleeen |last=Ollerenshaw |publisher=E. J. Morton |year=1982 |page=6}} Deaf since the age of eight, her fascination with mathematics was inspired by her Lady Barn headmistress, Miss Jenkin Jones. It was during her time at Lady Barn that she met her future husband, Robert Ollerenshaw. Today, Lady Barn House School recognises her as a 'Lady Barn legend' and she features heavily in a major historical display in the school Dining Room.{{cn|date=April 2018}} As a young woman, she attended [[St Leonards School]] and Sixth Form College in St Andrews, Scotland where today the house of young male boarders is named after her. At the age of 19 she gained admittance to [[Somerville College, Oxford]], to study [[mathematics]]. She completed her doctorate at Somerville in 1945 on "Critical Lattices" under the supervision of [[Theodore William Chaundy|Theo Chaundy]]. She wrote five original research papers which were sufficient for her to earn her [[Doctor of Philosophy|DPhil]] degree without the need of a formal written thesis.{{cn|date=April 2018}} While an undergraduate, she became engaged to [[Colonel (United Kingdom)|Colonel]] Robert Ollerenshaw, who became a distinguished military surgeon, a pioneer of [[medical illustration]]. They married in September 1939 and had two children, Charles (1941–1999) and Florence (1946–1972). In 1942 she suffered a miscarriage and "cried nonstop for three days" as a result of stress when her husband was suddenly mobilised and deployed for [[World War II|war]].{{cite news|title=Centenarian Dame Kathleen Ollerenshaw – Conqueror of Magic Squares, Rubik's Cube and Mauna Kea|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/dame-kathleen-ollerenshaw/|work=[[Scientific American]]|publisher=[[Nature Publishing Group]]|date=18 September 2012}} ==Career== After the Second World War, the Ollerenshaws moved to Manchester, where Kathleen worked as a part-time lecturer in the [[School of Mathematics, University of Manchester|mathematics department at Manchester University]] while raising her children and continued her work on lattices. In 1949, at the age of 37, she received her first effective hearing aid. [[File:Dame Kathleen Ollerenshaw MAS 2007.jpg|thumbnail|right|Kathleen Ollerenshaw, aged 95, at Manchester Astronomical Society in 2007]] Outside of academics, Ollerenshaw served as a [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] [[Councillor]] for [[Rusholme]] for twenty-six years (1956–1981), Lord Mayor of Manchester (1975–1976), [[High Sheriff of Greater Manchester]] from 1978 to 1979, and the prime motivator in the creation of the [[Royal Northern College of Music]]. She was made a [[Freedom of the City|Freeman of the City]] of Manchester and was an advisor on educational matters to [[Margaret Thatcher]]'s government in the 1980s. She was President of the [[Institute of Mathematics and its Applications]] from 1978 to 1979.{{cite web | url=http://www.ima.org.uk/about_us/institute_history/ima_presidents.cfm.html | title=IMA Presidents | publisher=[[Institute of Mathematics and its Applications]] |year=2014 | accessdate=4 August 2014 }} She published at least 26 mathematical papers, her best-known contribution being to [[Magic square|most-perfect pandiagonal magic squares]].{{cite web|url=https://ima.org.uk/publications/|title=Category : Publications|website=ima.org.uk}} Upon her death, she left a legacy in trust to support distinguished research visitors and public engagement activities at the [[School of Mathematics, University of Manchester]]. An annual public lecture at the University is named in her honour.{{cite web|url=http://www.mims.manchester.ac.uk/events/ollerenshaw-lectures/|title=Ollerenshaw lectures - The University of Manchester - School of Mathematics|website=www.mims.manchester.ac.uk}} An amateur astronomer, Ollerenshaw donated her telescope to [[Lancaster University]], and an [[observatory]] there bears her name. She was an honorary member of the Manchester Astronomical Society and held the post of Vice-President for a number of years. Ollerenshaw attended [[St Leonards School]] in [[St Andrews]], Fife, and served as the school's president from 1981 to 2003. She was succeeded by [[Hazel Byford, Baroness Byford|Baroness Byford]], [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] spokeswoman in the [[House of Lords]]. She [[centenarian|turned 100]] in October 2012.{{cite web|title = The 2012 Dame Kathleen Ollerenshaw Lecture|work = News|publisher = [[University of Manchester]]|date = 3 October 2012|url = http://www.manchester.ac.uk/aboutus/news/display/?id=8777|accessdate = 3 October 2012}} She died in [[Didsbury]] on 10 August 2014, at the age of 101.{{cite news | url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/dame-kathleen-ollerenshaw-former-lord-7597607 | author=Emma Flanagan | date=12 August 2014 | accessdate=12 August 2014 | publisher=[[Manchester Evening News]] | title=Dame Kathleen Ollerenshaw former Lord Mayor of Manchester dies aged 101 }} Her husband and both their children had predeceased her. ==Miscellanea== * Composer Sir [[Peter Maxwell Davies]] dedicated his [[Naxos Quartets|Naxos Quartet No.9]] to her.[http://www.naxos.com/catalogue/item.asp?item_code=8.557400 Listing from Naxos.com] ==Honours== In 1970, Ollerenshaw was appointed [[Order of the British Empire|Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] for services to education. ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== *Dame Kathleen Ollerenshaw, ''To Talk of Many Things: an autobiography'', Manchester Univ Press, 2004, {{isbn|0-7190-6987-4}} *Kathleen Ollerenshaw, David S. Brée: ''Most-perfect Pandiagonal Magic Squares: their construction and enumeration'', Southend-on-Sea: Institute of Mathematics and its Applications, 1998, 186 pages, {{isbn|0-905091-06-X}} *Kathleen Ollerenshaw, Herman Bondi, ''Magic Squares of Order Four'', Scholium Intl, 1983, {{isbn|0-85403-201-0}} *Kathleen Ollerenshaw, ''First Citizen'', Hart-Davis, MacGibbon, 1977, {{isbn|0-246-10976-9}} *K. M. Ollerenshaw; D. S. Brée, "Most-perfect pandiagonal magic squares", in: ''Mathematics Today'', 1998, vol. 34, pp. 139–143. {{ISSN|1361-2042}}. *D. S. Brée and K. M. Ollerenshaw, "Pandiagonal magic-squares from mixed auxiliary squares", in: ''Mathematics Today'', 1998, vol. 34, pp. 105–118. {{ISSN|1361-2042}}. ==External links== *[http://www.agnesscott.edu/lriddle/women/ollerenshaw.htm "Dame Kathleen Timpson Ollerenshaw", Biographies of Women Mathematicians], [[Agnes Scott College]] *{{MacTutor Biography|id=Ollerenshaw}} *{{MathGenealogy |id=86272}} *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/womanshour/2004_27_thu_01.shtml?wh_h_hdl Interview on BBC Radio 4] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110729160247/http://www.manchester2002-uk.com/celebs/politicians6.html Manchester Politicians, with biographical sketch] *[http://www.lancs.ac.uk/depts/physics/resources/observatory/ The Dame Kathleen Ollerenshaw Observatory at Lancaster University] *[http://www.manastro.co.uk The Manchester Astronomical Society] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ollerenshaw, Kathleen}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:Dames Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:People educated at St Leonards School]] [[Category:Alumni of Somerville College, Oxford]] [[Category:Conservative Party (UK) politicians]] [[Category:People from Withington]] [[Category:Amateur astronomers]] [[Category:British astronomers]] [[Category:20th-century British mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century British mathematicians]] [[Category:Mathematics educators]] [[Category:Women mathematicians]] [[Category:Women astronomers]] [[Category:Deaf politicians]] [[Category:Women mayors of places in England]] [[Category:Lord Mayors of Manchester]] [[Category:High Sheriffs of Greater Manchester]] [[Category:British centenarians]] [[Category:20th-century women scientists]] [[Category:Deaf people from England]] [[Category:Fellows of Somerville College, Oxford]] [[Category:Mathematician politicians]]

{{Infobox person | name = Luther P. Christman, PhD, RN, FAAN | image = Luther Christman photo from 1980.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Christman in 1980 | birth_date = February 26, 1915 | birth_place = [[Summit Hill, Pennsylvania]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2011|06|07|1915|02|26}} | death_place = [[Nashville, Tennessee]] | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = [[Michigan State University]]
Philadelphia Psychoanalytic Institute
[[Temple University]] | alma_mater = | occupation = Registered nurse
University professor
Administrator | years_active = | employer = | organization = | known_for = | notable_works = | influences = | influenced = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = | children = | awards = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Luther Parmalee Christman''' (February 26, 1915{{spaced ndash}}June 7, 2011) was an American nurse, professor of nursing, university administrator and advocate for gender and racial diversity in nursing. His career included service with the Michigan Department of Mental Health and academic posts at the [[University of Michigan]], [[Vanderbilt University]] and [[Rush University]]. In 1967, Christman became the first man to hold the position of dean at a nursing school. While serving as vice president for nursing affairs at [[Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center]], Christman implemented the Rush Model of Nursing, an influential model for delivering hospital nursing services. He was involved in the founding of the National Male Nurse Association, which later became the [[American Assembly for Men in Nursing]]. After his 1987 retirement, Christman received several awards and honors for his contributions to nursing. He died in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in 2011. ==Biography== ===Education=== Christman earned a diploma from the Pennsylvania Hospital School of Nursing for Men in 1939. He received an undergraduate degree from [[Temple University]] in 1948, then an Ed.M. degree in clinical psychology from the Philadelphia Psychoanalytic Institute. He completed a Ph.D. from [[Michigan State University]], where he studied anthropology and sociology.{{cite web|title=Dr. Luther Christman, Nursing Pioneer, Passes Away at 96|url=http://nursing.umich.edu/about-our-school/news-portal/201106/1704#.UUqWkr4o7IU|publisher=University of Michigan School of Nursing|accessdate=March 21, 2013}} Christman overcame gender discrimination during his own education; he was refused admission to two university nursing programs because he was male. While a nursing student, he was denied a maternity clinical rotation for the same reason. ===Career=== Christman said that he faced hostility from female coworkers early in his career, and that night shift positions in psychiatric nursing and urology were virtually the only openings for men.{{cite news|last=Markoutsas|first=Elaine|title=Medicine: Sex Roles Are Changing Slowly... But Changing|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9NJaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3lgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3458,1712243&dq=luther+christman&hl=en|accessdate=March 23, 2013|newspaper=The Evening Independent|date=January 9, 1979}} Christman was denied admission to the U.S. Army Nurse Corps on the basis of his gender; instead, he served in the U.S. Maritime Service as a pharmacist's mate during [[World War II]]. After returning from the war, Christman worked as a private duty nurse and assistant head nurse at [[Pennsylvania Hospital]]. After completing his Ed.M., he became director of nursing at Yankton State Hospital in South Dakota. In 1956, Christman went to work for the Michigan Department of Mental Health. In that position, he coordinated nursing school training at hospitals in the state. Christman was named associate professor of psychiatric nursing at the [[University of Michigan]] in 1963. In 1967, he assumed a dual role as nursing school dean at [[Vanderbilt University]] and director of nursing at [[Vanderbilt University Medical Center]]. In 1972, he took on similar responsibilities at [[Rush University]] and [[Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center]]. While Christman was at Rush, the school and hospital implemented the Rush Model of Nursing. The model highlighted the importance of clinical expertise among faculty members, which was similar to the established practice in medicine. His faculty practice model required that nursing professors spend most of their time in clinical practice. He retired in 1987.{{cite journal|last=Palmer|first=Jane|title=Luther Christman: Legacy of a Legend|journal=Reflections on Nursing Leadership|date=June 23, 2011|volume=37|issue=2|url=http://www.reflectionsonnursingleadership.org/Pages/Vol37_2_NoteFeat_Christman.aspx|accessdate=March 21, 2013}} During his career, Christman advocated for the advancement of nursing education. In the late 1960s, Christman predicted increased specialization in the next generation of nurses; he advocated for nurses to be freed of non-clinical tasks so that they could keep up with the nursing demands in an increasingly technological environment.{{cite news|title=New Breed of Nurses Seen|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NHFYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-vcDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7342,973175&dq=luther+christman&hl=en|accessdate=March 21, 2013|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=April 2, 1968}} In a 1978 presentation in Australia, he argued against systems which utilized a combination of registered nurses, nurse aides and student nurses; he highlighted statistics which showed that nurse aides were unoccupied up to 25 percent of the typical work day.{{cite news|last=McIlraith|first=Shaun|title=US Trend to Graduate-Only Nurses|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=X_tjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=feYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4071,7077445&dq=luther+christman&hl=en|accessdate=March 21, 2013|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=March 21, 1978}} Christman served multiple terms as president of the Michigan Nurses Association and he proposed the idea that led to the founding of the [[American Academy of Nursing]].{{cite book|title=Proud of Our Past, Preparing for Our Future:A History of the Michigan Nurses Association, 1904-2004|year=2004|publisher=Turner Publishing Company|page=52}} ===Awards and honors=== *Edith Moore Copeland Founders Award for Creativity, [[Sigma Theta Tau]] (1981) *Lifetime Distinguished Achievement Award (first recipient), Sigma Theta Tau (1991) *Living Legend, American Academy of Nursing (1995){{cite web|title=Living Legends |url=http://www.aannet.org/living-legends-complete-list |publisher=American Academy of Nursing |accessdate=March 21, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120412055058/http://www.aannet.org/living-legends-complete-list |archivedate=April 12, 2012 |df= }} *American Nurses Association (ANA) Hall of Fame (2004){{cite web|title=ANA Hall of Fame: 2000-2004 Inductees|url=http://nursingworld.org/FunctionalMenuCategories/AboutANA/Honoring-Nurses/NationalAwardsProgram/HallofFame/20002004Inductees|accessdate=March 21, 2013}} ===Later life=== Even after his retirement, Christman remained an active participant in nursing affairs for many years. He died of pneumonia on June 7, 2011 in Nashville. He was predeceased by his wife, Dorothy Black, in 2003. They had married in 1939 and had three children.{{cite journal|last=Jordan|first=Zoe|title=Remembering a Nursing Icon: Luther Christman (1915–2011)|journal=PACEsetterS|date=July–September 2011|volume=8|issue=3|pages=15–16|url=http://journals.lww.com/jbipacesetters/Fulltext/2011/07000/Remembering_a_Nursing_Icon__Luther_Christman.4.aspx|accessdate=March 21, 2013|doi=10.1097/01.jbi.0000405537.66667.b4}} ===Legacy=== In 1975, the American Assembly for Men in Nursing established the Luther Christman Award. The award recognizes "an individual or individuals who have made an outstanding contribution to nursing that also reflects highly on men in nursing or significantly contributes to the purposes of this organization."{{cite web|title=Awards: Luther Christman Award|url=http://www.aamn.org/awluther.shtml|publisher=American Assembly for Men in Nursing|accessdate=March 21, 2013}} In 2007, the American Nurses Association introduced a separate Luther Christman Award which "recognizes the significant contribution an individual man has made to the nursing profession."{{cite web|title=Luther Christman Award|url=http://www.nursingworld.org/FunctionalMenuCategories/AboutANA/Honoring-Nurses/NationalAwardsProgram/NatlAwards/LutherChristman-2|publisher=American Nurses Association|accessdate=March 21, 2013}} ==Selected works== *{{cite journal|last=Christman|first=Luther|title=Nurse-Physician Communications in the Hospital|journal=Journal of the American Medical Association|date=November 1, 1965|volume=194|issue=5|doi=10.1001/jama.1965.03090180063015|pages=539}} *{{cite journal|last=Christman|first=Luther|title=Nursing Leadership - Style and Substance|journal=American Journal of Nursing|date=October 1967|volume=67|issue=10}} *{{cite journal|last=Christman|first=Luther|title=The Clinical Nurse Specialist: A Role Model|journal=American Journal of Nursing|date=May 1970}} *{{cite journal|last=Christman|first=Luther|title=On The Horizon: The All-R.N. Nursing Staff|journal=Nursing Digest|date=October 1974|volume=2|issue=8}} *{{cite journal|last=Christman|first=Luther|title=The Practitioner-Teacher|journal=Nurse Educator|date=March–April 1979}} ==See also== *[[List of nurses]] *[[List of Living Legends of the American Academy of Nursing]] ==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Pittman|first=Elizabeth|title=Luther Christman: A Maverick Nurse - A Nursing Legend|year=2005|publisher=Trafford Publishing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k-d9GA2yrbMC&pg=PA1&dq=luther+christman+pharmacy&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=3#v=onepage&q&f=false}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Christman, Luther}} [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:2011 deaths]] [[Category:American nursing administrators]] [[Category:Deaths from pneumonia]] [[Category:Living Legends of the American Academy of Nursing]] [[Category:Nursing school deans]] [[Category:Male nurses]] [[Category:Nursing educators]] [[Category:University of Michigan faculty]] [[Category:People from Carbon County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:American academic administrators]]

{{distinguish|Michael Pawlyn}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox person/Wikidata | name = Michael Pollan | image = Michael Pollan at Yale 1 cropped.jpg | caption = Pollan speaking at [[Yale University]] in 2011 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|02|06}}{{cite web|url=http://michaelpollan.com/press-kit/|title=About Michael Pollan|work=michaelpollan.com|accessdate=October 12, 2015}} | birth_place = [[Long Island]], New York, U.S. | alma_mater = {{hlist|[[Bennington College]]|[[Columbia University]]}} | occupation = [[Author]], [[journalist]], [[professor]] | family = [[Tracy Pollan]] (sister)
[[Michael J. Fox]] (brother-in-law) | website = {{URL | michaelpollan.com | MichaelPollan.com }} }} '''Michael Pollan''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|ɒ|l|ə|n}} is an American author, journalist, activist, and the Lewis K. Chan Arts Lecturer and Professor of Practice of Non-Fiction at [[Harvard University]].{{cite web |title=Michael Pollan: Lewis K. Chan Arts Lecturer and Professor of the Practice of Non-Fiction |url=https://english.fas.harvard.edu/faculty/pollan/ |website=Harvard University Department of English |accessdate=9 August 2018}} Pollan is also professor of [[journalism]] at the [[UC Berkeley Graduate School of Journalism]].{{cite web |author=Graduate School of Journalism |title=Faculty: Michael Pollan |url=http://journalism.berkeley.edu/faculty/pollan |publisher=UC Berkeley |year=2008 |accessdate=2008-09-21}} ==Early years== Pollan was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family on [[Long Island]], New York.{{cite news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/50-most-influential-Jews-Places-31-40 |title=50 most influential Jews: Places 31-40 |date=May 25, 2012 |quote=Michael Pollan, 57 |author=STEVE LINDE|author2=A. SPIRO|author3=G. HOFFMAN |accessdate=May 26, 2013}}{{Cite web|last=Bloom|first=Nate|title=Jewish Stars 5/21 |newspaper=[[Cleveland Jewish News]]|date=May 21, 2010|url=https://www.clevelandjewishnews.com/archives/jewish-stars/article_8bcbaa8e-2f09-53ac-98ba-cd2207aa8901.html|accessdate=}} He is the son of author and financial consultant Stephen Pollan and columnist Corky Pollan.{{cite news |author=Helen Wagenvoord |title=The High Price of Cheap Food |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2004/05/02/CMGE560U5I1.DTL |work=The San Francisco Chronicle |date=May 2, 2004 |accessdate=2008-09-21}} Pollan received a B.A. in English from [[Bennington College]] in 1977 and an M.A. in English from [[Columbia University]] in 1981.{{cite news |author=Russell Schoch |title=Q & A: A Conversation with Michael Pollan |url=http://michaelpollan.com/interviews/q-a-a-conversation-with-michael-pollan/ |work=California Monthly |date=January 4, 2004 |accessdate=2011-09-12}} ==Career== ===''The Botany of Desire''=== In ''[[The Botany of Desire]]'', Pollan explores the concept of [[co-evolution]], specifically of humankind's evolutionary relationship with four plants — [[apple]]s, [[tulip]]s, [[cannabis (drug)|marijuana]], and [[potato]]es — from the dual perspectives of humans and the plants. He uses case examples that fit the [[archetype]] of four basic human desires, demonstrating how each of these [[botany|botanical]] species are selectively grown, bred, and [[Genetic engineering|genetically engineered]]. The apple reflects the desire for sweetness, the tulip beauty, the marijuana intoxication, and the potato control. Pollan then unravels the narrative of his own experience with each of the plants, which he intertwines with a well-researched exploration into their social history. Each section presents a unique element of human domestication, or the "human bumblebee" as Pollan calls it. These range from the true story of [[Johnny Appleseed]] to Pollan's first-hand research with sophisticated marijuana [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrids]] in [[Amsterdam]], to the alarming and [[paradigm]]-shifting possibilities of genetically engineered potatoes. ===''The Omnivore's Dilemma''=== In ''[[The Omnivore's Dilemma]]'', Pollan describes four basic ways that human societies have obtained food: the current industrial system, the big organic operation, the local self-sufficient farm, and the [[hunter-gatherer]]. Pollan follows each of these processes—from a group of plants [[photosynthesis|photosynthesizing]] calories through a series of intermediate stages, ultimately into a meal. Along the way, he suggests that there is a fundamental tension between the logic of nature and the logic of human industry, that the way we eat represents our most profound engagement with the natural world, and that industrial eating obscures crucially important ecological relationships and connections. On December 10, 2006, ''[[The New York Times]]'' named ''The Omnivore's Dilemma'' one of the five best nonfiction books of the year. On May 8, 2007, the [[James Beard Foundation]] named ''The Omnivore's Dilemma'' its 2007 winner for the best food writing. It was the book of focus for the [[University of Pennsylvania]]'s Reading Project in 2007, and the book of choice for [[Washington State University]]'s Common Reading Program in 2009–10. [[File:Michael Pollan.jpg|thumb|left|Michael Pollan speaks to the [[Marin Academy]] community.]] Pollan's discussion of the industrial food chain is in large part a critique of modern [[agribusiness]]. According to the book, agribusiness has lost touch with the natural cycles of farming, wherein livestock and crops intertwine in mutually beneficial circles. Pollan's critique of modern agribusiness focuses on what he describes as the overuse of corn for purposes ranging from fattening [[cattle]] to massive production of [[corn oil]], [[high-fructose corn syrup]], and other corn derivatives. He describes what he sees as the inefficiencies and other drawbacks of [[factory farming]] and gives his assessment of [[organic food]] production and what it's like to hunt and gather food. He blames those who set the rules (e.g., politicians in Washington, D.C., bureaucrats at the [[United States Department of Agriculture]], [[Wall Street]] capitalists, and agricultural [[Conglomerate (company)|conglomerates]] like [[Archer Daniels Midland]]) of what he calls a destructive and precarious agricultural system that has wrought havoc upon the diet, nutrition, and well-being of Americans. Pollan finds hope in [[Joel Salatin]]'s [[Polyface Farm]] in Virginia, which he sees as a model of [[sustainability]] in commercial farming. Pollan appears in the [[documentary film]] ''[[King Corn (film)|King Corn]]'' (2007). ===''In Defense of Food: An Eater's Manifesto''=== [[File:Michael Pollan at TED.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Pollan speaking at [[TED (conference)|TED]] in 2007]] Pollan's book ''[[In Defense of Food]]: An Eater's Manifesto'', released on January 1, 2008, explores the relationship with what he terms ''[[nutritionism]]'' and the Western diet, with a focus on late 20th century food advice given by the science community. Pollan holds that consumption of fat and dietary cholesterol does not lead to a higher rate of coronary disease, and that the reductive analysis of food into nutrient components is a mistake. He questions the view that the point of eating is to promote health, pointing out that this attitude is not universal and that cultures that perceive food as having purposes of pleasure, identity, and sociality may end up with better health. He explains this seeming paradox by vetting, and then validating, the notion that nutritionism and, therefore, the whole Western framework through which we intellectualize the value of food is more a religious and faddish devotion to the mythology of simple solutions than a convincing and reliable conclusion of incontrovertible scientific research. Pollan spends the rest of his book explicating his first three phrases: "Eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants." He contends that most of what Americans now buy in supermarkets, fast food stores, and restaurants is not in fact food, and that a practical tip is to eat only those things that people of his grandmother's generation would have recognized as food. ===''Food Rules: An Eater's Manual''=== In 2009, ''[[Food Rules: An Eater's Manual]]'' was published. This short work is a condensed version of his previous efforts, intended to provide a simple framework for a healthy and sustainable diet. It is divided into three sections, further explicating Pollan's principles of "Eat food. Not too much. Mostly plants." It includes his rules (''i.e.,'' "let others sample your food" and "the whiter the bread, the sooner you'll be dead"). ===''Cooked: A Natural History of Transformation''=== In ''[[Cooked: A Natural History of Transformation]]'', published in 2013, Pollan explores the methods by which cooks mediate "between nature and culture." The book is organized into four sections corresponding to the [[classical element]]s of Fire (cooking with heat), Water (braising and boiling with pots), Air (breadmaking), and Earth (fermenting), and features [[Samin Nosrat]], who later became known for the bestselling cookbook ''Salt, Fat, Acid, Heat,'' as "the chef who taught Michael Pollan how to cook."{{Cite news|url=https://www.motherjones.com/media/2017/04/samin-nosrat-salt-fat-acid-heat-soup-chez-panisse/|title=This simple advice completely changed the way I eat|work=Mother Jones|access-date=2018-10-28|language=en-US}} ===''How to Change Your Mind''=== In 2018, Pollan wrote ''[[How to Change Your Mind]],'' a book about the history and future of mind-altering substances. He argues that [[psilocybin]] and [[LSD]] are not drugs that make people crazy, which he calls the biggest misconception people have about psychedelics,{{cite news |last= OAKLANDER |first=Mandy |date=May 16, 2018 |title=This Will Change Your Mind About Psychedelic Drugs |url=http://time.com/5278036/michael-pollan-psychedelic-drugs/ |work=Time |access-date=May 16, 2018 }} but rather drugs that can help a person become "more sane," for example by eliminating a fear of death. While promoting his book on national TV, he explained that along with LSD and psilocybin, his research included ingesting [[ayahuasca]] and [[5-MeO-DMT]], and that he experienced a [[Ego death#Psychedelics|dissolution of ego]].[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LBOcWgMD49o Michael Pollan On The Healing Power Of Psychedelics] (Time, posted to YouTube on May 18, 2018)[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qzgtJleG3r8&t=2m22s Michael Pollan Tried A Series Of Psychedelic Drugs... For Research!] (The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, posted to YouTube on May 15, 2018) ===Other work=== Pollan is a contributing writer for the ''[[New York Times Magazine]]'' and a former executive editor for ''[[Harper's Magazine]]''. His first book, ''[[Second Nature (book)|Second Nature: A Gardener's Education]]'', was published in 1991. Pollan has contributed to ''Greater Good'', a social psychology magazine published by the [[Greater Good Science Center]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. His article "Edible Ethics" discusses the intersection of ethical eating and [[social psychology]]. In his 1998 book ''[[A Place of My Own]]: The Education of an Amateur Builder'', Pollan methodically traced the design and construction of the out-building where he writes. The 2008 re-release of this book was re-titled ''A Place of My Own: The Architecture of Daydreams.'' In 2014, Pollan wrote the foreword in the healthy eating cookbook ''The Pollan Family Table''. The book is co-authored by his mother, Corky Pollan, and sisters, Lori Pollan, Dana Pollan, and [[Tracy Pollan]]. Pollan also co-starred in the documentary, ''[[Food, Inc.]]'' (2008), for which he was also a consultant. In 2010 Pollan was interviewed for the film ''[[Queen of the Sun|Queen of the Sun: What are the bees telling us?]]'', a feature-length documentary about [[honey bees]] and [[colony collapse disorder]].[http://www.queenofthesun.com/2010/11/michael-pollan-author-omnivores-dilemma/ Michael Pollan]. ''Queen of the Sun''. He was also interviewed for ''[[Vanishing of the Bees]]'', a documentary also about colony collapse, directed by [[Maryam Henein]] and George Langworthy. In 2015, a documentary version of Pollan's book ''In Defense of Food'' premiered on PBS.{{Cite web|title = Watch Full Episodes Online of In Defense of Food on PBS|url = https://www.pbs.org/show/in-defense-of-food/|website = PBS|access-date = 2016-02-09|language = en-US}} In 2016, Netflix released a four-part documentary series, which was based on Pollan's book, ''Cooked'' (2013), and was directed by [[Alex Gibney]]. ==Recognition== In 2015, Pollan received the Washburn Award from the Boston Museum of Science, awarded annually to "an individual who has made an outstanding contribution toward public understanding and appreciation of science and the vital role it plays in our lives"{{Cite web|title = 2015 {{!}} Museum of Science, Boston|url = http://www.mos.org/washburn-award|website = www.mos.org|access-date = 2016-02-09}} and was named as a fellow at Harvard University's Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study.{{Cite web|title = Michael Pollan {{!}} Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University|url = https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/people/michael-pollan|website = www.radcliffe.harvard.edu|access-date = 2016-02-09}} He has also won the James Beard Leadership award,{{Cite web|title = James Beard Foundation|url = http://www.jamesbeard.org/blog/2014-jbf-leadership-award-honoree-michael-pollan|website = www.jamesbeard.org|access-date = 2016-02-09}} the [[Reuters]] World Conservation Union Global Awards in environmental journalism, the [[James Beard]] Foundation Awards for best magazine series in 2003, and the [[Genesis Award]] from the Humane Society of the United States. His articles have been anthologized in ''Best American Science Writing'' (2004), ''Best American Essays'' (1990 and 2003), ''The Animals: Practicing Complexity'' (2006), and the ''Norton Book of Nature Writing'' (1990). ==Criticisms== In the [[American Enterprise Institute]]'s magazine, Blake Hurst argues that Pollan offers a shallow assessment of factory farming that does not take cost into account.{{cite news |first=Blake |last=Hurst |title=The Omnivore’s Delusion: Against the Agri-intellectuals |url=https://www.aei.org/publication/the-omnivores-delusion-against-the-agri-intellectuals/}} Daniel Engber criticized Pollan in ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' for arguing that food is too complex a subject to study scientifically and blaming [[reductionism]] for today's health ills, while using nutritional research to justify his own diet advice. Engber likened Pollan's "anti-scientific method" to the rhetoric used by health gurus who peddle diet scams.{{cite news |first=Daniel |last=Engber |title=Survival of the Yummiest: Should we buy Michael Pollan's nutritional Darwinism? |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2158736|work=Slate}} Pollan's work has also been discussed and criticized by [[Jonathan Safran Foer]] in his non-fiction book ''[[Eating Animals]]''. Foer criticizes Pollan's argument regarding table-fellowship. According to Foer, Pollan claims that a vegetarian dinner guest causes socially reprimandable inconvenience for the host. Foer responds that in the year 2010 it is easier for hosts to accommodate vegetarians than locavores as hosts will need to do extensive research to find (expensive) non factory-farmed meat.{{cite web |title=Jonathan Safran Foer Takes on Michael Pollan |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NH-ZtLfoqaY |accessdate=May 10, 2012}} Pollan has been accused by [[Jon Entine]], who supports GMOs (genetically modified organisms), of using his influence to promote "anti-GMO junk science". A number of scientists and journalists have similarly characterized Pollan's work as biased against GMOs. For example, after Pollan posted a tweet that was critical of a ''[[New York Times]]'' article on GMOs, U.C. Berkeley biologist Michael Eisen posted a tweet calling Pollan's comment "a new low even in Pollan's 'anti-GMO crusade'".{{Cite web|title = Pointed talk: Michael Pollan and Amy Harmon dissect a GM controversy|url = http://grist.org/food/pointed-talk-michael-pollan-and-amy-harmon-dissect-a-gm-controversy/|website = Grist|access-date = 2016-02-09|language = en-US}}[https://www.forbes.com/sites/jonentine/2013/10/24/michael-pollan-promotes-denialist-anti-gmo-junk-science-brags-he-manipulates-new-york-times-editors/2/ Michael Pollan Promotes 'Denialist' Anti-GMO Junk Science, Says He Manipulates New York Times' Editors], Jon Entine. Forbes, October 24, 2013. In response to Pollan's statement that GMOs have been one "tremendous disappointment," food writer James Cooper criticized Pollan's tendency to cite poor or selected scientific sources.{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Food-Myths-Debunked-food-safe/dp/1502386003|title=Food Myths Debunked: Why our food is safe|last=Cooper|first=James W.|date=2014-09-27|publisher=CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform|isbn=9781502386007|language=English}} In 2014, Pollan co-hosted a discussion and informal debate on the topic of genetic modification at [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]] featuring prominent plant geneticist [[Pamela Ronald]], professor at [[University of California, Davis|UC Davis]], whose research-based position "strongly disagrees with Pollan’s view that G.M.O. crops, broadly, are failing."{{Cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/tech/elements/a-journalist-and-a-scientist-break-ground-in-the-g-m-o-debate|title=A Journalist and a Scientist Break Ground in the G.M.O. Debate|date=2014-04-25|website=The New Yorker|access-date=2016-12-22}} A ''New Yorker'' reporter observed that Pollan's largely anti-GMO student base at the discussion itself constituted, "a kind of monoculture," yet that Pollan sought "to introduce an invasive species" by engaging Ronald. The event, while predictably contentious, reportedly produced a rare instance of courteous, productive exchange between the two main sharply-opposed viewpoints on genetically-modified crops.
